RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH:
In 2013 and 2014 I joined the Applied Ethics and Bioethics team of the University of Urbino to develop experimental research projects dealing with the caregiving of chronic and neurodegenerative diseases. The first project, "Bioethics with the caregivers", was co-funded by the DISBEF (Dipartimento di Scienze di Base e dei Fondamenti) of the University of Urbino, the MARUZZA Foundation for Palliative Cares, and the Local Paediatric Association. The second project, "Bioethics with the caregivers in paediatrics", was co-funded by the DISBEF and the savings bank foundation of Pesaro. In 2012 I gained a PhD in Moral Philosophy from the University of Urbino "Carlo Bo" and Universitщ Paris Diderot-Paris VII with a thesis on the intentionality in dreaming (L'intenzionalitр nel sogno - l'intentionnalitщ dans le rъve). The PhD research was funded by the Italian government following a public competition. During my PhD course I spent on year and a half in Paris and gave seminars on the intentionality in sleeping at the UMR ACTE (Arts / Crщations / Thщories / Esthщtiques) of the Sorbonne University. In Italy I gave lectures and seminars at the faculty of Philosophy on the following subjects: "The concept of flesh in Aristotle , Life Function and Inner Life History, From the Daseinsanalyse to the Philosophical Practice . I developed the teaching course "The Dream between Philosophy and Psychopathology" at the Faculty of Psychology. Lectures include: From hypnosis to analysis , The dream as a symptom , Dream and Death , Phenomenological cues , and Giving: who to whom, what and why? Inquiry into an in-comprehensible act between Semantics and Anthropology .
Possui graduaчуo em Journalism - Universitр degli studi di Urbino "Carlo Bo" (2004), mestrado em Filosofia - Universitр degli studi di Urbino "Carlo Bo" (2003) e doutorado em Ethics - Universitр degli studi di Urbino "Carlo Bo" (2012). Tem experiъncia na сrea de Filosofia, com ъnfase em Щtica, atuando principalmente nos seguintes temas: dream, plato, socrates, rational imagination, derrida; gift; abandon; rest; dщpense; diffщrance;, being-toward-death, bewilderment, existence,, critical theory, body language, film studies, e communication theory, applied psychology.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Il sogno tra radicalismo scettico e realismo onirico

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Dreaming seems to involve a radical revision of every category of thought: sweeping away the belief in a subject-independent world,it wipes out the position of ingenuous realists and inline rationalists to radical scepticism. From Descartes to Freud, the oneiric phenomena have been banished to the non-place of conscience, outside the boundaries of reality. more in line with modern neuroscience, Aristotle highlighted the phenomenological role of sleep in awakening sleeping perceptions and reaffirming the oiriginal symbiosis between the soul and the world. Fro the ancient philosopher and doctor, dreams possess specific privileges of revelation, for it unfold the "demoniac" side of nature beyond the categories of intellect. hist multilevel perspective is today more topical and inspiring than ever, suggesting the direction of an integrated approach to the oneiric life

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Tra mondo proprio e mondo comune. Poђiesis e intenzionalitр nel discorso sacro di Eraclito

DETALHAMENTO-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-PERIODICO-OU-REVISTA: Isonomia, Rivista dell'Istituto di Filosofia Arturo Massolo

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: For Heraclitus there is no reality without dreaming. His over quoted saying that only waking people share a world in common has led to many equivocations. Since the western philosophy of dreaming and imagination begins here, it should be reconsidered after an accurate historical and philological contextualization and within Heraclitus‟ general conception of the oneiric world. This article is an attempt to provide a deeper insight to the author‟s thinking on imagery. It recapitulates the salient points of a more extended study on the obscure philosopher‟s anthropological background, its poietic imagery and its oneiric practices. The recurrent antithesis between the waking and sleeping states is analyzed at various levels of significance as a constitutive metaphor of the dialectic. After making the distinction between the philosophy of dream and the phenomenology of sleep, the intricate relationships between sleep, dream and death are taken under consideration. The dimension of intentionality and its role in Heraclitus‟ perception of reality is then explored by connecting the oneiric-related passages with other key fragments. The lѓgos of the philosopher is hence viewed as a poietic act and the instrument for nourishing the policy of the imagery. The extended study in which this article is grounded explores the connections of Heraclitus‟ thought with the trend of the physiologists (phisiolѓgoi) and the mystery cults which characterize Ephesus‟ naturalistic piety. Hercalitus‟ early conceptualization of the soul (ψυχή) is confronted with dionysism, orphism, and pythagorism; his oracular style re-assessed with respect to the ongoing passage from an oral to a written culture, and the parallel competition among different models of thinking. The study also provides arguments that Heraclitus‟ Sacred Discourse might contain hints to the practice of oneiric incubation.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Il resto e l'impossibile. (Ri)pensando al dono con Derrida

PALAVRAS-CHAVE.PALAVRA-CHAVE-1: Derrida; gift; abandon; rest; dщpense; diffщrance;

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The paradoxically inapparent figure of the gift represents one of the richest and fruitfully provocative developments of Jacques Derrida's philosophy of diffщrance. Alongside the dream and the trace, the gift must be analyzed in light of its intimate ambivalences and irreducible complexity. Using Deridda's reflection, it is possible to consider the gift as something akin to notes written in the margin of a printed page, where sudden insight and flashes of unpremeditated thought find their place without being confined to the text: the gesture of donating the French-Algerian philosopher finds the whole unpredictable and urgent щvщnщmentiel, the happening of event, which breaks the order of which it is a part. Marcel Mauss has already explored the fundamental paradox of the gift, which must be given unexpectedly and avoid any calculated cunning. Nevertheless it cannot be given without being taken thereby entering a circuit of exchange and, as such, the gift loses its very essence and meaning. The gift asserts itself at the expense of normative strategies: as a precious remainder of utilitarian and calculating reason and as possibility of the impossible and supremely paradoxical reality. In its preterintentional space, suspended in undecidability but constitutively oriented toward the other, thought is called upon to recover the gift from both the monodimensionality of the rational logos and the metaphysics of presence, the dia-logic multidimensional dimension, which is intrinsically open to transcendence: to recuperate the gift from the dimension of the dia, of the in- between, of the zwischen, which is constitutive of intersubjectivity.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-LIVRO.TITULO-DO-LIVRO: La bioetica con i caregiver. Alleanza terapeutica e qualitр della vita

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: With contributions from eighteen professional women counselors from twelve different countries, this book is the first to provide an overview of new-born philosophical practices from an entirely female perspective. It gives voice to women's thoughts and brings to the reader a living portrait of philosophy as a service to people and a training for those in search of a fully lived existence. As the authors draw on first-hand experience, their philosophical analyses intertwine with changes in attitudes and real-life stories, unearthing that forgotten soul of philosophical thought which our ancestors referred to as the Anima. The book provides a lively, sprightly and vivacious picture of how philosophy is used in practice, a long way from the rigidness and stereotypical severity of its traditional image. It will not fail to inspire readers to live their thoughts and think their lives. Contributions from: Lydia Amir (Israel), Camilla Angeltun (Norway), Narelle Arcidiacono (Australia), Silvia Bairdjian (Argentina), Helen Douglas (South Africa), Ora Gruendgard (Israel), Rayda Guzmсn Gozсnlez (Spain), Dena Hurst (USA), Roxana Kreimer (Argentina), Marie-France Lebouc (Canada)Kate Mehuron (USA), Marleen Moors (Netherlands), Riella Morhaiym (Turkey)M.G. Piety (USA), Natasa Radovanovic (Serbia, )Heidi Salverrэa (Germany), Luisa Sesino (Italy, )Marianne Vahl
